Taxonomy and Systematics of South American Sericini
Project
Taxonomic revision of South American Sericini

45 Tons into the past: Estimating paleobiodiversity of the Crato Formation (Aptian, Cretaceous, NE Brazil) based on a known amount of sediment.
Project
A well delimited sampling (a know amount of any larger natural systems being investigated) is the base for ecological analysis, and is the first steep toward implementing statistic models for biodiversity estimation. The Lower Cretaceous Crato Formation of Brazil is one of the world’s most important fossil deposits, exhibiting exceptional preservation. This fossil assemblage includes a large range of organisms, from macrophytes ranging from ferns to some of the earliest angiosperms; palynomorphs; large arthropod diversity including arachnids, crustaceans and an immense number of insect groups, as well as vertebrates such as fishes, anurans, lizards, turtles, crocodiles, pterosaurs and birds.1,2,3The Crato Formation has the most diverse fossil assemblage for any non-marine Cretaceous locality in Gondwana, and perhaps Laurasia1 (See examples of Crato Formation fossils housed in the Fossil Collection of the Dept of Biology and Zoology -UFMT in the link https://photos.app.goo.gl/Yg1q6uKhouocHtab6 ). This project aims to investigate the complete fossil assemblage from 45 tons of sediments from the Crato formation, which commonly includes arthropods, plants and fishes remains, to provide the first quantitative inventory of this splendorous fossil locality. Our aims include the inference of common ecological index, such as richness, abundance and community structure. This inventory also have a large potential of the discovery of new fossil species, specially of small organism, usually neglected in difficult field collecting conditions. The sediment were obtained as a donation from local mining industry for cement and paving stones (Fig.1). Its consists on the basal Crato formation unity of laminated limestones know as the Nova Olinda Mamber. The fossil-rich rocks were transported from Nova Olinda, CE, NE Brazil to the Campus of the Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso, MT, Central Brasil, about 3,000 km from the collecting site (Fig.2). Collection and material preparation will be done with the collaboration of the undergraduate students of the Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso (Figure 3). All voucher specimens will be deposited in the Coleção de Fósseis do Departamento de Biologia e Zoologia, Universidade Federal de Mato Grosso- UFMT (Fossil Collection of the Department of Biology and Zoology, Federal University of Mato Grosso State – UFMT). References 1. Martill, D., Bechly, G. & Loveridge, R. The Crato Fossil Beds of Brazil: Window Into an Ancient World. (Cambridge University Press, 2007). 2. Brito, P. M. & Yabumoto, Y. An updated review of the fish faunas from the Crato and Santana formations in Brazil, a close relationship to the Tethys fauna. Nat. Hist. Hum. Hist., Ser. A 9, 107–136 (2011). 3. Moura-Júnior, D. A., Scheffler, S. M. & Fernandes, A. C. S. A Paleoentomofauna Brasileira: Cenário Atual. The Brazilian Fossil Insects: Current Scenario. Anuário do Instituto Geociências - UFRJ 41, (2018).

Systematics of the Neotropical genus Polynoncus Burmeister, 1876 (Coleoptera, Scarabaeoidea, Trogidae)
Project
The objective of this work is directed at elucidating the evolutionary relationships among the species of the genus based on morphology, to reconstruct genealogical ties among the gemmingeri-group based on molecular markers, and to formalise and update the taxonomy of the genus. It will contribute to improving the information of Polynoncus, by providing an integrated line of evidence (morphological and molecular) by which to understand and study the group’s evolutionary history and relationships, and information on the Trogidae in general.
